thread.title: Apple Pay becomes another reason to gripe about U.K. banks
thread.title_full: Apple Pay becomes another reason to gripe about U.K. banks - MarketWatch

author: By     Trey Williams
title: Apple Pay becomes another reason to gripe about U.K. banks
text:
When Apple Inc. launched Apple Pay in the U.K. on Tuesday, consumers expressed both excitement and frustration — a reaction reminiscent of Apple’s U.S. launch in April.
Like in the U.S., Apple Pay AAPL, +0.96% allows consumers in the U.K. to make easy, contact-less purchases at select merchants with no more than a fingerprint. And like in the U.S., some consumers had problems getting the system set up.
Another frustration for some was HSBC PLC HSBA, +0.10% one of the U.K.’s largest retail banks with around 16 million U.K. customers. It had ben expected to be part of the launch, given that it was featured on the Apple Pay website. But the bank’s customers weren’t able to link their accounts to Apple Pay on Tuesday, according to the BBC. The bank said it hadn’t planned to take part in the launch.
Apple didn’t respond to requests for comment. HSBC said in a tweet to one angry customer that it would launch Apple Pay later this month.
Read: Apple, Google seek the ‘Holy Grail’ of mobile payments
Apple had announced plans to make the move overseas during its development conference in June. Apple Pay was supposed to launch with eight banks and 250,000 locations, with a big emphasis on its ability to pay for tickets on London transit.
Also see: Apple Pay had exciting announcements during WWDC too, Drake
Here’s how Twitter reacted to Apple Pay’s U.K. launch and the absence of HSBC:
@HSBC_UK When are you launching Apple Pay, you have cheated many people that switched for that reason only. What date can we expect?
— James (@James_Ford_) July 15, 2015 . @HSBC_UK Dude, where's my #ApplePay ?
— Melissa Therms (@MelissaTherms) July 15, 2015 HSBC wasn’t the only bank receiving grief and questions about its absence from Apple Pay.
Apple Pay is currently available through NatWest, Nationwide, Royal Bank of Scotland, Ulster Bank and Santander, but payments are usually limited to £20 for now, according to the BBC.
